results.title: The Choice
results.brief_description: The staff of a high school newspaper decide to do an issue on the drug problem, by dividing into two groups to research the pros and cons of drug taking. Projects the message that before a choice is made in favour of the non-medical use of drugs one should be fully aware of the dangers to mental and physical health inherent in such a choice. Intended mainly for school children. NOTE: Restricted to tertiary institutions, teaching hospitals, police and customs departments.

results.title: The Chinese girl = La Chinoise
results.creator_credit: De La Gueville, Anouchka Films, Parc Film and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: This experimental non-linear work, about five students who embrace Maoism, heralded the second wave of Godard’s filmmaking - The Revolutionary. Spending the summer in the bourgeois surrounds of a borrowed flat, the students become immersed in the doctrine of Chairman Mao’s Little Red Book, discussing methodologies (which include terrorism and assassination) to overthrow governmental systems. Heralded by some as groundbreaking cinema that subverted popular notions of filmmaking (recall Godard’s famous quote: “A story should have a beginning, a middle and an end, but not necessarily in that order”), “La Chinoise” also confounded many Godard admirers with its obscure polemic. Cast includes: Juliet Berto, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Anne Wiazemsky and Blandine Jeanson.

results.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
results.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Folktales from around the world”.
An animated story about a Chinese potter who makes a beautiful porcelain teapot for the Emperor who regards its worth as priceless. It is then seen to be desirable and is inevitably stolen from the Emperor’s palace. In a series of transactions that follow in various parts of the world, it is exchanged for items from other cultures that are equally regarded as priceless. Provides a simple introduction to the notion of trade, as well as the economic and aesthetic considerations involved in the determination of the worth of a product. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: The Children of Bet Alpha
results.creator_credit: Phoenix Films, Ritzau Film and Krosney
results.brief_description: An intensive look at Israel’s communal approach to raising children, shot at Kibbutz Bet Alpha. Looks at four age groups within Bet Alpha - infants, three year olds, seven year olds and twelve year olds. The camera records the children’s behaviour and the film describes in detail Bet Alpha’s approach to collective education which in many ways preceded other modern approaches to education.

results.title: The Children must learn
results.creator_credit: Educational Film Institute of New York University, Documentary Film Productions and Willard Van Dyke
results.brief_description: Designed to illustrate the unsatisfactory relationship between education and the local necessities of life which characterises education in many parts of the USA. The film presents a study of farm families in the poorer mountain communities of the rural south, inadequately housed and clothed, ill-fed, living onland which yearly returns them less and less. One of the first tasks of education is to ensure that the children’s school curriculum meets the needs of their daily life.

results.title: The Children's hour [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: William Wyler Productions and William Wyler
results.brief_description: An irresponsible, neurotic child spreads a slanderous rumour about a lesbian relationship between the two headmistresses of an exclusive private girls’ school. Wyler and executive producer Walter Mirisch decided to return to the play by Lillian Hellman that had been the basis of the 1936 production, ‘These Three’, also directed by Wyler. This time they intended to remain faithful to the play to an extent that had not been possible in the earlier film due to the restrictive Production Code. However, ‘The Children’s Hour’ was attacked by critics for being too faithful to what they saw as the dated original (a criticism with which Hellman herself apparently concurred). What stands up today is Hepburn’s understated playing and MacLaine’s commitment to the role of a possessive lesbian. This was the first major Hollywood production to deal with lesbianism although the word is never actually spoken. Cast includes Audrey Hepburn, Shirley MacLaine, James Garner, Miriam Hopkins, Fay Bainter.
